The attorneys who've been with us longest almost all started that way.

objection_technology.objection: I don't need all that fancy technology - basic transcripts are fine

objection_technology.authentic_response: You're right that not every deposition needs real-time or video sync. Here's what we've learned: Attorneys who say that usually haven't experienced how real-time changes cross-examination. When you can search the transcript instantly for what the witness said two hours ago and confront them with the exact quote, it's a completely different deposition. But we don't push technology you don't want - we offer it when it makes sense for your case. Many attorneys start with standard transcripts and then request real-time once they're preparing for trial on a complex case. You control what you need.

objection_technology.proof_element: Case study showing how real-time transcription changed deposition outcome

thread_structure: You think court reporting is just typing fast? Let me show you what a Tuesday actually looks like. Buckle up:
6 AM: Wake up. Check equipment. Backup equipment. Backup to the backup. (Yes, really.)
7 AM: Drive to courthouse. Realize the deposition moved to a law office 40 minutes away. Redirect.
8:30 AM: Set up stenograph. Test audio backup. Swear in witness. Attorney is late. We wait.
9 AM: Deposition starts. Medical malpractice case. 87 medical terms in the first 10 minutes. I know them all.
11 AM: Attorney asks me to read back testimony from 45 minutes ago. I do it verbatim. They're shocked every time.
12 PM: Lunch? No. Another deposition across town starts at 1 PM. Eat protein bar in car.
1-4 PM: Construction defect case. Technical engineering terms. Heated arguments. I'm capturing every word at 225 WPM.
5 PM: Back home. Now the REAL work starts. Editing, proofing, formatting transcripts. Deadline: tomorrow 9 AM.
8 PM: Transcript delivered. Start studying new medical terminology for tomorrow's case. Sleep. Repeat.

This job requires: 
- 2-4 years training
- 98% accuracy
- Legal knowledge
- Tech skills
- Mental stamina
- Zero room for error
And we're the invisible backbone of the justice system. RT if you had no idea court reporters did all this.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: Legal terms you're probably saying wrong (from someone who transcribes them 40 hours/week):
thread_structure: Legal terms you're probably saying wrong (from someone who transcribes them 40 hours/week):

1. Voir dire = 'vwahr deer' NOT 'voyer dyer' 
(It's the jury selection process. French origin.)

2. Subpoena = 'suh-PEE-nuh' NOT 'sub-pee-nuh' 
(That first syllable matters in court.)

3. Affidavit = 'af-ih-DAY-vit' NOT 'af-ih-david' 
(I've heard 'david' more times than I can count.)

4. Deposition = 'dep-oh-ZISH-un' NOT 'dee-position' 
(You're being deposed, not repositioned.)

5. Litigant = 'LIT-ih-gant' NOT 'lit-ih-GANT' 
(Emphasis on the first syllable.)
Pro tip: If you're testifying, ask your attorney to go over pronunciation. It builds credibility.
Court reporters notice EVERYTHING. Including when attorneys mispronounce their own motions.
Follow for more legal insider knowledge from the people who literally record every word.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: Confession: After 15 years as a court reporter, I still get nervous before high-stakes cases. Here's what I've learned about managing pressure:
thread_structure: Confession: After 15 years as a court reporter, I still get nervous before high-stakes cases. Here's what I've learned about managing pressure:
1. The nerves mean you care. The day you stop being nervous about accuracy is the day you should quit.
2. Preparation eliminates 90% of anxiety. Know the case, study the terminology, check your equipment twice.
3. You're not just a typist. You're the official record. That's a responsibility, not a burden.
4. Attorneys rely on you more than they admit. When they ask for read-backs, you're their safety net.
5. The stenograph doesn't care about pressure. It responds to muscle memory. Trust your training.
6. Every reporter misses a word sometimes. The difference is catching it during editing, not hiding it.
7. High-profile cases are just cases. The stakes don't change your job—accurate transcription at 98%+.
The pressure is real. The skill is earned. The responsibility is sacred. This is why we train for years.
If you're a new court reporter feeling imposter syndrome: You belong here. The nerves prove it.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: 10 things court reporters wish attorneys actually understood (but are too professional to say out loud):
thread_structure: 10 things court reporters wish attorneys actually understood (but are too professional to say out loud):
1. We can't transcribe you if you're talking over each other. One at a time. Please.
2. 'Off the record' means STOP TALKING until we say we're back on. Not 'whisper your strategy.'
3. Spelling names at the start saves everyone time. 'Mr. Wojciechowski' has 47 possible spellings.
4. We hear everything. Including what you think you're mumbling under your breath.
5. Asking us to read back 20 minutes of testimony takes time. Maybe take notes?
6. 'Can you type faster?' We're already at 225 WPM. The limit is your speaking speed, not our typing.
7. We're not court stenographers. We're certified court reporters. The title matters.
8. Eating during deposition? We can hear the chewing. It's in the audio backup. Forever.
9. We've been doing this longer than you've been practicing. Trust the process.
10. We're not just service providers. We're officers of the court. Respect goes both ways.
Attorneys who get this? You're our favorites. We'll move mountains for you.
Follow for more unfiltered insights from the people who record your every word. Literally.
